Award.AwardTitle: EAGER - GLOBE (NSF16-031): Collaborative Research: Leveraging GLOBE student and citizen science data on the Flyover Country mobile platform for place-based, data-driven education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will focus on developing the capacity to expose and visualize GLOBE data collected by citizen scientists and students in the geoscience mobile app Flyover Country (FC). This application for mobile devices displays Earth data and geologic maps drawn from public databases, and caches this information on the mobile device for offline use. The user can then access a wealth of curated geoscience content while in flight, on a road trip, or on a hike. In addition to presenting GLOBE data alongside with other data, the project will develop associated visualization and interactivity functions for FC. These functions include a "mission" or "call to action" for the user to collect GLOBE observations if his or her driving FC path intersects a region that is underrepresented with respect to GLOBE data; a time slider to visualize changes in data point values over time (i.e., the past 20 years of GLOBE data collection); and an application programming interface to improve access to GLOBE data. These functions will be of great utility not only to the GLOBE user cases, but also to all users of FC and potential users/analysts of GLOBE data. GLOBE data in FC will also benefit from novel cartographic visualization strategies being developed.

It is expected that GLOBE data will accessible to the 100,000 users of FC. In addition, there is the possibility of developing new exercises for use in classrooms where computers may be limited, but access to mobile devices may be more within reach. The investigators will assess the use of FC-with-GLOBE in the classes at a community college, and use the same assessments with other groups, including diverse undergraduate students conducting research, Native American students in K-12 science camps, and students in attending universities and field camps. The results will be shared in one or more publications. The promotion of the GLOBE Program to the academic research community, through the incipient development of FC as a research application, will raise awareness of the program as a highly desirable partner for developing meaningful broader impacts activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flyover Country is a map-based, place-based mobile app that enables users to access cultural and geological information for any point on the map, and identifies important landscape features in the vicinity. Ideal for use in both formal and informal educational settings, as well as for use by interested individuals, the app promotes place-based exploration of Earth system science and human cultural features on the landscape. 

This project merges these innovative features with scientific observations reported by citizen scientists using The GLOBE Program’s GLOBE Observer app. The visualization of these data in the Flyover Country app creates a view of science that is inclusive of both the research outcomes of professional scientists and citizen scientists, and highlights the importance of citizen science by making it visible in the same interface. Users of the app can select the map layers they wish to view, customizing the maps viewed in the Flyover Country interface to the interests of the viewer. 

The GLOBE Observer application programming interface (API) was completed in mid 2019. This allowed the project to enable visualization of GLOBE citizen scientist data as a data layer in the Flyover Country app. Other apps and services can now take advantage of this API for any purpose. 

The second innovation created in this project was to promote and encourage the collection of scientific data using the GLOBE Observer app. A goal of this project was to combine the capabilities of data visualization with a call for data collection. The technological innovation made operational through this project is an ability for scientists seeking observational data for a specific region to enter a data request. For instance, a local ecologist might be studying tree succession after a fire, or a land cover specialist may want to have an ambiguous feature identified in satellite data examined and reported by a citizen scientist in the area. A person who is using the Flyover Country app will be served with a notification, “Scientist needs tree height measurements in your area. Can you help?” The app provides a button the user can click to enter the GLOBE Observer app and make and upload scientific observations. If the user does not have the GLOBE Observer app, they are directed to the app store where they can download the free app and install on their mobile device, creating the link between the two apps. 

You can download Flyover Country and the Globe Observer app today, for free, on both Android and iOS devices.
